Award.AwardTitle: Sociotechnical Interventions for Nurturing Successful Team Learning Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the need for collaboration in the workplace increases, teaching teamwork is important for preparing students to be successful in their chosen careers. Instructors who want to incorporate teamwork into their courses face challenges: how to group students into effective teams given the learning goals and, once formed, how to support teammates in connecting to create a successful learning experience. Today, instructors struggle to address these challenges, often delegate team formation to the students themselves, and conduct few, if any, activities aimed at team development. This project will produce 1) technological innovations that will enable instructors to algorithmically group students into teams with effective compositions given the learning goals and 2) intervention activities to nurture the foundations of teamwork such as team identity and psychological safety in those teams. The activities and technological innovations will be motivated by relevant theories, refined through design sessions with stakeholders, and empirically tested in university courses. The project outcomes have the potential to help the many instructors assigning team projects decide (1) how to best group students into teams given the context-specific goals of a course, (2) how to achieve those best groups with an intelligent team formation tool, and (3) how to help teams create the psychological safety that fosters success. Students are expected to benefit by being assigned to teams where they can best utilize their individual strengths, by experiencing a fairer team formation process, and by learning how to engage with teammates most effectively. Graduate students aiding the research activities in this project will gain knowledge and skills in human-computer interaction, learning science, and computer science, and will learn about the interdisciplinary design and research process necessary to create successful cyberlearning tools.

This project investigates, in large course settings, a conjunction of new algorithmic team formation and social techniques, to support team development. The project integrates social and learning science and technology design to advance knowledge of (1) how team composition relates to collaborative process, team performance, and team satisfaction for specific learning goals; (2) learnersourcing techniques to generate team compositions that students prefer and to involve them in configuring these compositions in a team formation tool; (3) interventions to help a team develop foundations for successful learning experiences and guidelines for which interventions teams should perform, given the team’s composition and goals; and (4) how different categories of learners perceive the value and fairness of algorithmic team formation and how they make that determination. These four research goals will be addressed through a design-based research methodology—where an iterative approach is applied to the design, deployment, and evaluation of both the technology and the interventions—drawing from theories of learning, team composition, and team building. The research efforts will advance our knowledge of how best to support collaborative learning activities and progress toward a future where instructors can combine social processes and intelligent tools to deliver effective team-based learning experiences for all students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Instructors who want to incorporate teamwork into their courses face two significant challenges: how to group students into effective teams given the learning goals of the course and, once formed, how to support these teams of possible strangers to establish the necessary foundations to have a successful learning experience. Through this award, the PIs addressed these challenges by developing new pedagogical methods and interventions, novel human-centered tools, and experimental results to help instructors group students into teams and nurture effective teamwork.

For team formation, instructors are increasingly using AI-based tools to group students into teams. These team formation tools typically require the instructor to determine a weighted criteria configuration and enter it into the tool to guide the grouping algorithm. Deciding the best configuration is challenging and the instructors’ choices may not align with the preferences of those who will be most impacted by these decisions - the students. 

As an outcome of this project, the PIs developed a new method that an instructor can deploy to generate a student-defined criteria configuration for a team formation tool. Building on collection innovation theory, students estimate the weights for a collection of preliminary criteria determined by the instructor, discuss their estimates in an online forum, and then revise their estimates in an effort to reach consensus. The aggregated configuration can then be entered into a team formation tool. From deploying the method in multiple project-based courses and analyzing the resulting configurations, the PIs found that students prefer to be grouped with other students who share a similar level of course commitment and compatible schedules the most, then with students who have different demographic attributes, and then with students who have diverse  task skills. Instructors can apply these results to guide team formation in their own courses or replicate the method to gather student preferences for team formation in any course. 

A second outcome was the development of a new interactive tool that students can use to perform evidence-based peer evaluations of their teammates. The tools extracts, aggregates, and visualizes the interaction log data that is auto-captured by the use of digital tools students commonly use for team projects. Students can interact with the visualization to annotate important contributions from their teammates and contextualize their own contributions. The benefit of the tool is to scaffold accurate, fair, and differentiated peer ratings and mitigate the influence of social and cognitive biases (e.g., peer pressure) during the peer review process.

Another related outcome was the development of a Web-based interactive dashboard that generates evidence-based feedback on a team’s collaborative process relative to expected behaviors (e.g., team members should have an equal distribution of work and should demonstrate early and steady progress toward a final solution). The platform also processes the log data captured by the use of digital collaborative tools. Students can leverage these research-based visualizations to learn and practice positive teamwork behaviors, such as balanced work distributions and practicing early starts and steady progress. Instructors can leverage the dashboard to discover authentic patterns of teamwork in their courses, proactively diagnose problems within teams, and develop evidence-based solutions to help teams succeed. A final outcome developed in this project demonstrated that interventions such as team contracts can have a positive impact on teamwork and these contracts should be explored at different stages of a project alongside computational efforts to assess collaborative groups’ progress. 

The research outcomes of this project have enabled new pedagogies in courses that incorporate team-based learning (e.g., enabling students to collectively determine how an algorithm will group them into teams and evidence-based tools for performing peer evaluations) and these pedagogies have been implemented in project-based computing and education courses taught by the PIs. The award has created research opportunities for five doctoral students, two master’s students, and four undergraduate students. These students received training in human-computer interaction, computer science, teamwork science, experimentation, and scientific communication. The outcomes of this project have been deployed in courses taught by the PIs and have improved the team-based learning experiences for 800+ students at the PIs’ university. More broadly, the research opportunities and pedagogical advances enabled by this award have contributed to a U.S. workforce that is better equipped to develop and apply technology innovations for solving complex problems through teamwork.
